Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Story: I glanced at my phone as the passenger slid into the back seat, his voice tense. “Please, I need to catch the 7:10 train. Can you get me there in time?” I nodded, shifting into drive, but my mind was elsewhere. My mentor’s message blinked on the screen: “Don’t forget to finish the code sample before our meeting. Looking forward to seeing your progress!” I’d barely started the assignment, and every minute behind the wheel was a minute lost. But now, the passenger’s anxious glances in the rearview mirror pressed on me. He was counting on me to navigate the rush hour chaos and get him to the station safely and quickly. My mentor expected focus and dedication, but my job demanded my full attention on the road. I felt the weight of both responsibilities, my hands tightening on the steering wheel as I wrestled with the urge to pull over and work on my code, even as the city lights blurred past and the clock ticked down.
